title: Quiz 7: Sampling & Ethics
description: Test your knowledge on how to select study subjects and ensure ethical conduct.

questions.question: ___BLANK___ is the entire group of persons or objects the researcher wants to study, while a ___BLANK___ is a representative subset of that group.
questions.explanation: Population is the whole; Sample is the part selected for study.

questions.question: Match the sampling method to its type:
questions.explanation: Random/Cluster are probability (random chance). Quota/Purposive are non-probability (judgment/convenience).

questions.question: Which sampling technique involves selecting every 'nth' individual from a list (e.g., every 10th person)?
questions.explanation: Systematic sampling uses a sampling interval (n) to select subjects.

questions.question: If your population is 2000 and your desired sample size is 200, what is your sampling interval (n)?
questions.explanation: 2000 divided by 200 equals 10. You pick every 10th person.

questions.question: Which ethical principle relates to the right to self-determination and the protection of vulnerable groups (like children)?
questions.explanation: Respect for persons ensures autonomy and protects those with diminished autonomy.

questions.question: The Principle of Justice includes which of the following rights? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Right to fair selection and treatment

questions.explanation: Justice covers fairness, privacy, and confidentiality. 'Do no harm' is Beneficence.

questions.question: Convenience sampling (accidental sampling) allows the researcher to strictly control for sampling bias.
questions.explanation: False. Convenience sampling takes whoever is available, making it impossible to control bias or ensure representation.

questions.question: Which sampling method is used when the population has natural groupings, and you select a sample of these groups?
questions.explanation: Cluster sampling selects groups (clusters) rather than individuals initially.

questions.question: What is 'Snowball Sampling' typically used for?

options.text: Hidden populations difficult to access (e.g., drug users)

questions.explanation: Snowball sampling relies on subjects recruiting their acquaintances, useful for hidden/hard-to-reach populations.

questions.question: What must be included in an informed consent explanation? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Consent requires transparency about purpose, risks, and privacy. Coercion (large rewards) is unethical.
